YESTERDAY'S ASSEMBLY

FIFTH REGIMENT MEET
Continued from page I,

and Blue hope to repeat last year's
performance by winning the meet.
For the first time since the inauguration of the games, negro athletes are debarred from participation. The following has been sent
out with the circular announcing
the meet:
The Games Committee has been
granted the use of the Armory for
these indoor games, with the distinct understanding that colored or
negro athletes will not be allowed
to enter the games as contestants.
This statement is made in advance
to avoid embarrassment to those
concerned later on.

WORK TO START ON NEXT YEAR'S
HANDBOOK

The Y. M. C. A. expects to begin work on next year's Handbook or to use more familiar language, the "Freshman's Bible."
There are several positions open
for those who wish to give some
time to this essential work. All
desiring to apply for places as
business manager or as one of the
editorial staff may turn in their
names, class, P. 0. box and the
position they desire to apply for,
to the "Y" officer or to the "Y" P.
0. box. All undergraduate students are eligible.

The explanation of the Honor System given at yesterday's
Assembly is very timely and should clear up any misapprehension
still existing in the minds of new students concerning its efficacy
and the method of procedure.

THE INTELLECTUAL
Recently the intellectual has been the target of a volley of reproaches. He has been harried, villified and scorned. A wave of
antagonism to him followed the war mania, since mob suspicion
•••

was sure to detect in him the menacing red streak of a revolutionary. Conditions have little changed within the last few years, and
the intellectual is still an object either of benevolent contempt or
downright hostility.
But what is this peculiar -sort of a creature we dub an intel-

3

lectual? Is he the wild-eyed malcontent and mystic rebel so threateningly pictured by the yellow press who find no cruelty painful
enough to ascribe to him? Or is he the weak-willed blind enthusiast,
striving after butterfly creations of his imagination. Indeed, there
are some who are all that and perhaps the world is right in denouncing them.
But far more numerous and important are those groups of intellectuals who see in society and in life more than the primitive
rudimentary elements of food getting, self preserving, and replenishing the earth. They view life as capable of being moulded to the will
of men and fashioned to their ideas and ideals. They find in life
mystic interests and subtle values unconceived by the man of the
street. They regard culture as the highest achievement of the human
heart.

We worked on Camels for years before we

blending—experimenting with the world's

The true intellectual is one who, silently working in his mental

OS

laboratory, plans and thinks, and hopes to add his atom of strength
and knowledge to the compcund wisdom of the ages. He a.one keeps

•••

alive the fires on the hearthstones of art, literature and philosophy.
MI

He alone has the power and vision to guide and predict.
Against such types the world can least afford to bear

•MI

The tragedy lies in the poverty of their numbers rather than in the
•••

peculiarities of their manner or teaching. Our country has yet to
learn to put a premium on its intellectuals and thereby give impetus
to those forces that make for a higher American life.—"The Daily
Cardinal."

The South Door of Gilman Hall,
Returning perhaps for something
forgotten,
Late in the afternoon,
Or on Saturday afternoon:
And we find the door locked.
And then we walk South,
And then walk East,
And then North, and then West:
All the way around the tennis
courts,
About a quarter of a mile:
To reach a door on the next floor,
Which was almost over our heads!

much longer are the professors going to insist upon seizing a man
twice a year, shoving him into a
classroom, slamming an exam before him and telling him to sort
out of his overworked and muddled brain a few isolated facts that
wi.1 look good on paper? Certainly an examination does not
give the average man a chance to
demonstrate what he has learned
in the past four months. And then,
too, the enormous amount of knowledge that is crammed up for an
examination is forgotten a few
hours after the zero hour is past.
Hopkins is one of the few universities left in the country that stiil

certainly seems that the man who

and does good work should be rewarded by being given exemptions.
This system is now being employed
by the Military Department and an
examination or the marks on record

The Social Science Club announced last Tuesday that the
lecture on "The Closed Shop,"
which was to have been delivered
at 4 o'clock that day in the hall of
the Civil Engineering Building,
had been cancelled. This was due
to the sudden illness of the lecturer, Mr. James O'Connel, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation
of Labor.

and Blue hope to repeat last year's

For the first time since the inauguration of the games, negro athletes are debarred from participation. The following has been sent
out with the circular announcing
the meet:
The Games Committee has been
granted the use of the Armory for
these indoor games, with the distinct understanding that colored or
negro athletes will not be allowed
to enter the games as contestants.
This statement is made in advance
to avoid embarrassment to those
concerned later on.

The Y. M. C. A. expects to begin work on next year's Handbook or to use more familiar language, the "Freshman's Bible."
There are several positions open
for those who wish to give some
time to this essential work. All
desiring to apply for places as
business manager or as one of the
editorial staff may turn in their
names, class, P. 0. box and the
position they desire to apply for,
to the "Y" officer or to the "Y" P.
0. box. All undergraduate students are eligible.

THE INTELLECTUAL
Recently the intellectual has been the target of a volley of reproaches. He has been harried, villified and scorned. A wave of
antagonism to him followed the war mania, since mob suspicion
•••

was sure to detect in him the menacing red streak of a revolutionary. Conditions have little changed within the last few years, and
the intellectual is still an object either of benevolent contempt or
downright hostility.
But what is this peculiar -sort of a creature we dub an intel-

3

lectual? Is he the wild-eyed malcontent and mystic rebel so threateningly pictured by the yellow press who find no cruelty painful
enough to ascribe to him? Or is he the weak-willed blind enthusiast,
striving after butterfly creations of his imagination. Indeed, there
are some who are all that and perhaps the world is right in denouncing them.
But far more numerous and important are those groups of intellectuals who see in society and in life more than the primitive
rudimentary elements of food getting, self preserving, and replenishing the earth. They view life as capable of being moulded to the will
of men and fashioned to their ideas and ideals. They find in life
mystic interests and subtle values unconceived by the man of the
street. They regard culture as the highest achievement of the human
heart.

The true intellectual is one who, silently working in his mental

OS

laboratory, plans and thinks, and hopes to add his atom of strength
and knowledge to the compcund wisdom of the ages. He a.one keeps

•••

alive the fires on the hearthstones of art, literature and philosophy.
MI

He alone has the power and vision to guide and predict.
Against such types the world can least afford to bear

•MI

The tragedy lies in the poverty of their numbers rather than in the
•••

peculiarities of their manner or teaching. Our country has yet to
learn to put a premium on its intellectuals and thereby give impetus
to those forces that make for a higher American life.—"The Daily
Cardinal."

The Social Science Club announced last Tuesday that the
lecture on "The Closed Shop,"
which was to have been delivered
at 4 o'clock that day in the hall of
the Civil Engineering Building,
had been cancelled. This was due
to the sudden illness of the lecturer, Mr. James O'Connel, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation
of Labor.
